Back to Robert Schumann

Robert Schumann

Carnaval, op. 9

1834–1835

[Wikipedia] · [IMSLP]

Total duration: 31'

  • 1. Préambule
  • 2. Pierrot
  • 3. Arlequin
  • 4. Valse noble
  • 5. Eusebius
  • 6. Florestan
  • 7. Coquette
  • 8. Réplique
  • 9. Sphinxes
  • 10. Papillons
  • 11. A.S.C.H.–S.C.H.A. (Lettres dansantes)
  • 12. Chiarina
  • 13. Chopin
  • 14. Estrella
  • 15. Reconnaissance
  • 16. Pantalon et Colombine
  • 17. Valse allemande
  • 18. Paganini: Intermezzo
  • 19. Aveu
  • 20. Promenade
  • 21. Pause
  • 22. Marche des ‘Davidsbündler’ contre les Philistins
  • Capriccio

Schumann prepared four further pieces for this collection, as well as a sketch for a capriccio, that he ultimately rejected. The complete pieces later became the third Albumblätter (no. 6) from Bunte Blätter (op. 99), and the Walzer (no. 4), Romanze (no. 11) and Elfe (no. 17) from the Albumblätter (op. 124).

Recommended editions

  • Gesamtausgabe (Schott) · III/1/2 · RSA 1017 · ed. Michael Beiche
  • Henle · HN 922 · Sämtliche Klavierwerke / Band II · ed. Ernst Herttrich
  • Henle · HN 923 · Sämtliche Klavierwerke / Band II · ed. Ernst Herttrich
  • Henle · HN 187 · ed. Ernst Herttrich
  • Wiener Urtext · UT 50206 · ed. Michael Beiche

1. Préambule

Schumann used the same theme in the introduction to the Variationen über den Sehnsuchtswalzer von Franz Schubert (Anh. F24).

Duration: 2' 30"

Difficulty: 3.5

Duration: 2'

Difficulty: 3

Difficulty: 3

8. Réplique

Duration: 1'

Difficulty: 3

9. Sphinxes

Between Réplique and Papillons, Schumann includes three small fragments called Sphinxes. These contain simply the notes E-flat, C, B and A (no. 1); A-flat, C and B (no. 2); and A, E-flat, C and B (no. 3). They are usually not played.

Difficulty: 3.5

Capriccio

A short sketch exists for an additional piece that was not included in the final collection.
